content: Others might overthink the problem. IMO it could be solved well within 10 mins if we simply use if-else blocks. Not hard at least for me.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because I think it's an interesting problem to solve.

I found it to be a fun puzzle to solve. However, based on the comments and my own experience, it seems to take more than 15 minutes for a lot of people including myself.

One of the ways to simplify it could asking people to print the coefficients ac (ad+bc)  bd separated by spaces and any 0 coefficient be replaced by a space. eg: output 1   -9 instead of x^2 - 9 for the test case Difference of Two Squares.

 This is just suggestion but I think any simplification would be a good idea to decrease the average solution time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pared down well to fit into a CoC.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Really great problem! I finished in around 20 minutes, so I feel like it's a bit long for Coc. It also would be nice if, in the examples, some of the other special cases were added.

This one is pleasant to solve, probably a bit too long for a Coc though. 
I think it would be a great medium training puzzle.
Interesting
Seems like this would be a fun one to get for shortest mode. Overall I really like this one.

I think you need to clarify in your statement that you don't actually just want the expansion "ac + ad + bc + bd", you want it to be simplified into the form "ax^2 ± bx ± c" - you explain that in "Output" but the statement is misleading.

It took me to long as well to finish it (+-18 min), most of the time was spent getting the inputs right. Maybe you can consider a version where the inputs are given not as a string but as 4 integers (a,b,c,d), where the output does have to be the expansion for the given binomial product.
It's a fun problem, but it took me 20 minutes to solve it. Because there are many particular cases.

I solved all but the last case in 13 minutes. I was able to complete the last portion with an additional 3 minutes (outside the time limit). I thought this was a great exercise, but I believe this is too difficult for CoC. With the text parsing, accounting for the negatives, the missing "1", removing zero terms, there is too much going on. I believe this needs some simplification for CoC or to be a classic puzzle. Great job on the test cases and write up!

I believe "Coefficient is an integer that cannot be 1 or 0" is incorrect. Your examples include the coefficient of 1 (x by itself implies coefficient 1).

I think the least fun is the text parsing portion. If the input were "a b c d" and they were parsed in the stub It think that would be a great step towards making this reasonable for a clash.
Could you consider turn on the reverse mode?
I turned reverse mode on as it is still completely viable to complete without the statement.

I think your timing criticism is valid—not all people will be able to solve this in time—but I think having a good text parsing strategy is important for CoC.

The reason I said, "Coefficient is an integer that cannot be 1 or 0" is because that would imply that "1x" is valid (only "x" would be valid). I can definitely word this better, though, so I will be sure to do that.

I may rework this to remove the text parsing, but I'd like to hear what others think about it before I do so. 

If people think that this is too difficult, I may move this problem to a classic puzzle and create a simplified version for CoC.

Thank you for the detailed feedback!
Thank you!

It has already been significantly simplified, the other comments are referring to the old version. The original had input given in the form "(x + 3)(x + 2)" rather than "1 3 1 2". I think that this is more than doable within 15 minutes. I feel as though simplifying it more would make the problem rather trivial. Not all CoC have to be easy. I appreciate the feedback though.
Wonderful, feel free to ping me again after your revisions.
